fields.title: Nvidia Stock Rises As Chip Giant's 'Awakening' Touted, But Is It A Buy Now?
fields.text:
Nvidia (NVDA) stands at the forefront of artificial intelligence and machine learning, powering a future of self-driving cars, cloud gaming and data centers. Nvidia earnings for the first quarter underscored that the chipmaker's data center business is growing by leaps and bounds. So is Nvidia stock a good buy now?

For those looking for top large-cap stocks to buy now, here's a deep dive into NVDA stock.

Nvidia Stock Technical Analysis
Nvidia stock's IBD Composite Rating is an unbeatable 99. In other words, it's in the top 1% of all stocks based on combined technical and fundamental metrics. The IBD Stock Checkup tool can help you find other chip stocks with superior composite ratings. Investors generally should focus on stocks with CRs of 90 or even 95.

Shares of the chip giant have almost doubled from the March coronavirus lows. They surged 21.5% in May alone on strong Q1 results.

Nvidia stock is well extended from a 275.50 cup-with-handle buy point cleared in early April. Investors who bought NVDA stock at that price could consider taking some profits now, but shares are acting well.

The chip stock also is well above the 50-day line and 200-day line after undercutting them in the coronavirus stock market rout. While the major stock market indexes and many other growth stocks are now back above their 50-day lines, Nvidia stock found bullish support at this key level earlier.

In fact, NVDA stock continues to far outperform the broader market, seen in a rising relative strength line. The RS line for Nvidia stock is just below all-time highs pegged in late May, according to MarketSmith chart analysis.

The RS line, the blue line in the chart shown, tracks NVDA stock's performance vs. the S&P 500 index. It is well off the two-year low reached in early June 2019.

In May, Nvidia stock surged as Q1 earnings showed its gaming and data center businesses continue to see robust growth.

NVDA stock is a well-traded stock backed by institutions: 3,149 funds owned Nvidia stock as of March. That was up from 2,901 funds in December.

Nvidia stock has an RS Rating of 97, meaning it has outperformed 97% of all stocks over the past year. It's a top holding in the iShares PHLX Semiconductor ETF (SOXX), along with rival AMD stock. Both Nvidia and AMD belong to the IBD 50 list of top growth stocks.

Nvidia Earnings And Fundamental Analysis
The Nvidia stock EPS Rating is a best-possible 99 and its SMR Rating is an A, on a scale of A to E, with A tops. The EPS rating reflects a company's health on fundamental earnings metrics, and its SMR Rating gauges sales growth, profit margins and return on equity.

In May, the graphics-chip maker crushed earnings estimates, earning $1.80 a share on sales of $3.08 billion. On a year-over-year basis, Nvidia earnings jumped 105% while sales climbed 39%, following a 136% EPS gain on 41% revenue growth in the prior quarter. Notably, Nvidia's data-center revenue rose 80% to $1.14 billion, helped by early Ampere shipments. This marked the first quarter in which the fast-growing business topped $1 billion in sales. Core gaming revenue rose 27% to $1.34 billion, and several analysts raised price targets on NVDA stock.

"While the shares remain expensive, there are frankly few true growth stories in semiconductors these days, and even fewer with Nvidia's current execution," wrote Bernstein analyst Stacy Rasgon. "And even if expensive, we see no rationale to sell here, given product cycles on the way and a profile that continues its awakening toward a true accelerated computing company with every passing quarter."

Nvidia returned to sales and earnings growth in Q4 of fiscal 2020 after four straight down quarters. Like other chipmakers, Nvidia was hobbled by a cyclical downturn in semiconductor sales.

When Nvidia next reports, around mid-August, analysts expect Q2 EPS to jump 57% to $1.95 as revenue grows 42% to $3.65 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research. Wall Street sees Nvidia earnings per share increasing 36% to $7.90 in all of 2021, and growing a further 22% to $9.62 in 2022.

Over the past three years, Nvidia earnings per share grew by an annual 14% and sales by 10%. While that's solid enough, it's below the 25% or better a CAN SLIM investor would want to see in a top growth stock.

Nvidia's strong fundamental position also is reflected in a 35% annual pretax margin and 33% return on equity.

The company completed its $7 billion Mellanox acquisition on April 27, as it doubles down on data centers while positioning for leadership in AI and deep learning.

In case of broad semiconductor weakness, some experts advise investing in the highest-growth end markets of AI, self-driving cars, data centers and gaming. Nvidia taps those markets.

NVDA Stock Basics
The fabless chipmaker pioneered graphics processing units to make video games more realistic. It's shifting to artificial intelligence chips, which have new and expanding uses in supercomputers, data centers and driverless cars.

Nvidia competes against AMD in chips for gaming as well as Bitcoin mining. It vies with Intel (INTC) in data-center processors, with AMD (AMD) also making a push into that market. Nvidia's data-center business counts Amazon.com (AMZN), via Amazon Web Services, as a customer.

Nvidia and Intel control the AI chip market, where Qualcomm (QCOM) is making inroads. Nvidia is partnering with VMware (VMW) and Amazon on an AI-driven cloud platform for big businesses.

Semiconductor stocks are volatile. They rallied early this year on signs of an industry recovery and on a U.S.-China trade deal, then sold off on coronavirus fears. In 2019, the U.S. blacklisting of Huawei during the trade war weighed on many chipmakers. Huawei restrictions remain an issue for many chipmakers in 2020.

Chinese telecom giant Huawei relies on U.S. suppliers for its smartphones and networking devices. Both Nvidia and AMD derive 1% to 2% of revenue from Huawei. Other companies are more exposed.

Meanwhile, Nvidia stock and other chip stocks are among the hardest hit from a China trade war.

Semiconductor sales will rebound to 5.9% growth in 2020, research firm IHS Markit predicts. Global chip sales rose 13% in 2018 and fell an estimated 13% in 2019.

The growth of 5G wireless has stimulated demand for semiconductor products. However, the coronavirus pandemic is threatening the nascent semiconductor industry recovery. First, the deadly virus halted production in China. Then, as it spread worldwide, the pandemic caused the global economy to skid.

NVDA And Rival Chip Stocks
NVDA stock and AMD stock are established leaders in the semiconductor industry, though Nvidia has been outperforming AMD in recent weeks.

Nvidia's other rivals include Intel, Ambarella (AMBA), Broadcom (AVGO) and Xilinx (XLNX).

Among top chip stocks, Nvidia, AMD and data-center Inphi (IPHI) currently lead IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group. Fabless chip companies, including Nvidia and Qualcomm (QCOM), contract with foundries to make the chips they design. Other chip companies own their fabrication plants.

Nvidia is ranked No. 3 out of roughly 30 fabless semiconductor stocks tracked by IBD. The fabless chip stocks group itself ranks No. 10 out of 197 industry groups and is showing strong price momentum.((

For the best returns, growth stock investors should focus on companies that are leading the market and their own industry group.

Nvidia Stock Is Not A Buy
On a fundamental level, Nvidia earnings and sales are rising again after sharp declines. The chip company's also strong on other key measures such as profit margins and return on equity.

The Mellanox acquisition expands Nvidia's cloud and data center opportunity.

Nvidia is a leader in the fabless chip group, showing strong momentum as industry headwinds ease. But some analysts suggest the coronavirus risk could chill the electronics end market through 2020.

On a technical basis, Nvidia is extended from a buy point after selling off initially on coronavirus fears. The rising RS line reflects NVDA stock's outperformance as the stock market recovers and rallies.

Bottom line: Nvidia stock is not a buy. But as a top-rated chip stock, it's certainly one for your investing watchlist.

fields.title: Is Advanced Micro Devices Stock a Buy?
fields.text:
Semiconductor designer Advanced Micro Devices (NASDAQ:AMD) is a big winner these days. The stock has been crushing the broader market as well as archrivals Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) and Nvidia (NASDAQ:NVDA) over the last two years:

Is AMD's stock still a buy after these dramatic gains? Let's have a look.
Valuation

This is not a cheap stock. AMD's share prices are holding up fairly well in the COVID-19 health crisis, falling just 6.5% since the onset of global coronavirus worries in February. Over the same period, Intel's stock fell 11.5%, and the S&P 500 market barometer dropped 14%.

Even a dramatic plunge wouldn't have made an obvious value stock out of AMD. The stock is trading at nosebleed valuation ratios: around 130 times trailing earnings and 150 times free cash flows. Buying AMD shares today amounts to a vote of confidence in CEO Lisa Su, who has made a habit out of delivering on AMD's promises. The company hasn't missed Wall Street's earnings targets since the fall of 2015, and the company's financial results tend to land exactly where analysts expected -- based on AMD's official guidance targets.

Analysts and investors see a long-term success story developing under Su's steady hand. Without that trust, AMD's stock wouldn't be valued like a high-octane growth stock.

Business prospects

COVID-19 lockdown orders boosted the PC market in the last couple of months as office workers and students prepared to get their work done from home. Laptop sales are particularly strong right now.

That upside will shift into a downside for the next couple of quarters as the initial rush to pick up home office fixtures fades. Rising unemployment figures and uncertainty in the business world will weigh on AMD's sales instead. The most significant upside to the rest of 2020 should come in the second half of the year, as both Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) and Sony (NYSE:SNE) ramp up component orders for their next-generation gaming consoles. AMD won the design bids for central processors and graphics systems in both of these surefire hit products.

Under these circumstances, AMD expects second-quarter sales to land near $1.85 billion, a 21% increase over the same period in 2019. For the full fiscal year, the company expects 25% year-over-year revenue growth and a final top-line tally of approximately $8.4 billion. Three months ago, when the coronavirus felt like a distant threat on Chinese shores, the full-year sales target stood at $8.7 billion.

The upshot: Hold your horses

AMD's upswing in recent years is very convincing, and the stock may indeed have legs, but the chipmaker's shares are also priced for absolute perfection. I wouldn't bet against Lisa Su by selling AMD's stock short, but it wouldn't take much of a slip to send those skyrocketing stock prices back to earth in a hurry.

In short, AMD's stock is best watched from the sidelines until its valuation starts to make sense.

fields.title: Is It Too Late to Buy Novavax Stock?
fields.text:
This month, the U.S. government awarded Novavax (NASDAQ:NVAX) more funding than any other company in the coronavirus vaccine race. In response, the shares surged by 32% in one trading session. Operation Warp Speed, the government's effort to help bring a vaccine to market by January, awarded the biotech company $1.6 billion. That's more than the $1.2 billion it offered to big-pharma rival AstraZeneca (NYSE:AZN) and the $483 million awarded to Moderna (NASDAQ:MRNA), the first company to bring a COVID-19 vaccine into human trials.

The move surprised the market, as Novavax wasn't on the government's list of five companies to potentially receive funding. (AstraZeneca and Moderna were.) Investors may wonder whether this new vote of confidence -- and other factors -- will lead to more share gains. Or is there little potential left in this biotech stock?

If Novavax's only advanced program were the COVID-19 vaccine, I would be very hesitant about buying the stock at this level. On optimism about COVID-19 vaccine development, the shares have risen 24-fold so far this year. That's a lot for a company that isn't yet profitable and doesn't have any products on the market.

NanoFlu on the fast track
But what makes me optimistic about the shares for the long term is Novavax's flu vaccine. In a phase 3 clinical trial, NanoFlu met all primary endpoints. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration had already granted the vaccine fast-track status, and now the company plans to use the agency's accelerated pathway to seek approval. Novavax hasn't said when it plans to file, but with strong phase 3 data in, a regulatory submission is on the horizon.

We know there are other flu vaccines out there. As a matter of fact, nine vaccine options were available this past season. So why should we be excited about NanoFlu? One reason is its performance against a market leader. When compared with Sanofi's (NASDAQ:SNY) Fluzone, NanoFlu outperformed its rival in antibody response measures. Another reason: Analysts predict peak sales of NanoFlu may be between $550 million and $1.7 billion. And finally, the global flu vaccine market, at a 7.7% compound annual growth rate, is expected to reach $7.3 billion by 2026, according to Fortune Business Insights.

Still, with attention on COVID-19 these days and the global need for a vaccine, you might wonder why I'm more focused on Novavax's flu program than on its coronavirus efforts. Here's why: COVID-19 still represents an unknown. We don't know how long the pandemic will last, how much revenue a vaccine will generate, or even how many of the players will successfully bring a product to market. We still don't know whether Novavax will even make it to the finish line. The flu market represents fewer unknowns. Novavax's NanoFlu clinical trial results make me optimistic about approval prospects -- and we can count on vaccine revenue every flu season.

Another reason to own Novavax shares
This doesn't mean we should shrug off the COVID-19 vaccine progress or the importance of Operation Warp Speed's investment in Novavax. Beyond NanoFlu, I see the COVID-19 vaccine candidate as an additional reason to own Novavax shares. The funding means Novavax can bring the vaccine candidate through late-stage clinical development all the way to approval and afford a large-scale manufacturing ramp-up to produce 100 million doses as early as this year.

Novavax expects to report interim phase 1/2 immune response and safety data later this month. The phase 2 part of the trial will begin shortly thereafter, and Novavax aims to start phase 3, involving as many as 30,000 participants, in the fall.

Now let's talk share price. In spite of recent gains, Wall Street's average estimate indicates the stock could advance 17% from here within the next 12 months. NanoFlu and the COVID-19 investigational vaccine are two major catalysts for Novavax. The former in the long term, the latter in the near term.

I agree with Wall Street. Novavax shares may have further to go, even from today's level, and I like NanoFlu's long-term prospects. Still, I wouldn't recommend the stock to all investors at this point because the near term represents a good deal of risk.

The market may greatly reward -- or severely sanction -- Novavax based on COVID-19 clinical trial news in the coming months. As I always say, anything can happen during clinical trials. For that reason, only aggressive investors with risk appetite should consider buying this biotech stock right now.

fields.title: Is The Ultimate Warren Buffett Stock A Buy Amid The Coronavirus Rally?
fields.text:
Warren Buffett is widely regarded as one of the greatest investors of all time. One way to share in his success is to invest in his firm, Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB). Berkshire Hathaway stock is building a base, but is it a buy as stocks rally following the coronavirus crisis? Let's take a close look at the fundamental and technical performance of the ultimate Warren Buffett stock.

Berkshire Hathaway is a conglomerate that owns some of America's most famous firms. It wholly owns the likes of Geico, Duracell, Dairy Queen, Fruit of the Loom and rail operator BNSF.

Berkshire Hathaway Stock
Berkshire Hathaway is perhaps more famous for serving as an investment vehicle for Warren Buffett and his top lieutenant, Charlie Munger. Following their value investing philosophy, Berkshire Hathaway owns huge stakes in American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO) and other heavy hitters.

But the definition of a Warren Buffett stock has evolved in recent years. Warren Buffett became a big investor in airlines such as Delta Air Lines (DAL), but was left to rue his decision to go against his own long-held views about that industry's profitability. The move blew up in his face as airline stocks were decimated due to the global coronavirus pandemic.

Under investment managers Todd Combs and Ted Weschler, Berkshire Hathaway has been increasingly sinking money into tech, taking large positions in established giants like Apple (AAPL), as well as younger companies like Brazilian payments company StoneCo (STNE). Berkshire also snapped up a stake in Amazon.com (AMZN).

Warren Buffett has also been spending more on stock buybacks. Nevertheless Berkshire slowed stock repurchases to $1.7 billion in Q1 from $2.2 billion in Q4, as he looks to protect his empire by insulating it with cash.

Berkshire Hathaway Coronavirus Exposure
As well as its status as an investment vehicle, Berkshire Hathaway is a conglomerate in its own right. It has interests in segments such as railroads, utilities and energy. Those sectors, along with other "real economy" companies that are Warren Buffett staples, have been hard hit by the coronavirus shutdowns and massive economic contraction.

It has big exposure to the insurance sector by way of its ownership of Geico. States such as California are ordering insurers to give partial credits or refunds of premiums in lines such as private passenger automobile insurance, commercial automobile insurance, workers' compensation insurance and commercial liability insurance. Geico is the second largest auto insurer in the United States, after State Farm. In addition, insurance companies look set to get hit by an increase in demand for policy payouts in areas such as travel insurance, and for paying out any policies that include contagious disease coverage.

Berkshire also owns BNSF Railway Company, the largest freight railroad network in North America. But profits will also be hit here due to the sudden economic contraction affecting the level of demand for its services. Union Pacific (UNP) and CSX (CSX) have already warned their businesses could see significant financial impacts.

Other wholly owned businesses such as Dairy Queen, multilevel marketing company Pampered Chef, Fruit of the Loom, aviation training company FlightSafety International and real estate giant Long & Foster are also sure to be hit by the coronavirus recession.

Warren Buffett's Big Gas Bill
Warren Buffett has been criticized for the size of his cash pile. But it emerged July 6 he had finally put it to use to make his biggest acquisition in years with a $10 billion deal for Dominion Energy (D) assets.

Berkshire seized the chance to secure Dominion 's gas pipeline network after the utility giant and Duke Energy (DUK) unexpectedly aborted plans to build the Atlantic Coast Pipeline.

Berkshire Hathaway Energy will buy about 7,700 miles of natural gas transmission pipelines and 900 billion cubic feet of gas storage. The all-cash deal includes $4 billion of equity and $5.7 billion of debt. It's set to close in the fourth quarter.

"We are very proud to be adding such a great portfolio of natural gas assets to our already strong energy business," Buffett said in a statement.

Berkshire Hathaway Ejects Airline Stocks
Warren Buffett's firm revealed at its virtual annual meeting in May that it has sold off all of its airline holdings. This was part of a larger sell-off of $6.1 billion of net equities in April alone. It has sold its shares of Delta Air Lines, United Airlines (UAL), American Airlines (AAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV). The industry is currently facing a 95% drop in air travel.

Berkshire initially sold off millions of shares of Delta Air Lines and Southwest Airlines amid the coronavirus crisis, according to regulatory filings released in early April.

These initial sales made up a relatively small part of Berkshire Hathaway airline investments. It still owned around 59 million shares of Delta and 51.3 million shares of Southwest Airlines following the sales.

The sell-off came despite Warren Buffett asserting earlier in March that he had no plans to sell airline stocks. In February, Berkshire Hathaway disclosed it bought more Delta Air Lines shares.

Virus Infects Warren Buffett Portfolio
Overall, the firm's stock portfolio has taken a spanking amid the market drawback. Its biggest holdings include Apple, American Express, Bank of America (BAC) and Coca-Cola.

Airlines and restaurants look sure to have long-term issues even after the economy reopens. Financials are also struggling, as a combination of what could be a historic recession and record-low interest rates send investors fleeing bank stocks.

Finally, Warren Buffett made a big bet on shale just before crude oil prices crashed, taking a $10 billion stake in Occidental Petroleum (OXY) in 2019 as it outbid Chevron (CVX) for Anadarko Petroleum. With global energy demand plunging during the coronavirus crisis, shale operations are largely unprofitable now.

Warren Buffett has had some winners. Apple, Amazon, drugmaker Biogen (BIIB) and consumer staples retailer Kroger (KR) are among the stocks in Berkshire Hathaway's lineup of U.S.-listed stocks that are up this year.

Other Buffett Blunders
There have been missteps that have damaged the Berkshire Hathaway stock portfolio even before the coronavirus crisis, such as large stakes in troubled Wells Fargo (WFC) and Kraft Heinz (KHC). In fact, the firm is still carrying its Kraft investment at $13.6 billion, when its fair value is $8.1 billion, CFRA analyst Catherine Seifert said in a May 4 research note.

The Warren Buffett approach serves as a ready-built diversified portfolio for investors. But is this mix of wholly owned companies, blue chip stocks and a hand-picked selection of younger companies — along with massive insurance operations — enough to make Berkshire Hathaway stock a buy? Read on.

Warren Buffett Placed These Bets
Berkshire Hathaway's most recent 13-F filing was made late May, and it showed Buffett had shuffled his hand as he sought to take make the best of the difficult market conditions.

He snapped up shares of PNC Financial Services (PNC) and U.S. Bancorp (USB) in Q1, but tapped out of positions in Travelers (TRV) and Phillips 66 (PSX). He also reduced his Amazon stock exposure as the coronavirus took down global markets.

He also trimmed his stake in Goldman Sachs (GS) by 84%, while reducing his position in JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Synchrony Financial (SYF) by 3% apiece, Sirius XM (SIRI) by 2%, and Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA), VeriSign (VRSN) and DaVita Healthcare (DVA) by 1% each.

Minor portfolio changes included Berkshire reducing Amazon by 0.7%, or 4,000 shares. Buffett revealed a stake in Amazon a year ago, valued at roughly $1 billion today. He also cut Biogen (BIIB) by 0.8%, or 5,425 shares

One of Berkshire's core positions is in Apple stock. He maintained his position, and it remains the No. 1 stock in Buffett's portfolio at 36.5% of assets. Stakes in the other top 10 stocks in its portfolio were unchanged.

Berkshire Hathaway Stock Technical Analysis
Amid the coronavirus-related stock market pullback, Berkshire Hathaway stock plummeted. MarketSmith analysis shows it has recovered somewhat from its woes, and is still within a consolidation pattern, technically. But it remains far from its ideal buy point of 231.71. It could also go on to potentially build a base with a lower buy point of 203.43, but this remains some ways off.

BRKB stock submarined below its 50-day moving average in late February. The stock finally managed to retake the key technical benchmark on May 27, but has been struggling to hold above it after slipping back below it June 11. Berkshire stock hit resistance near its 200-day line in early June and has slumped since then.

The relative strength line of Berkshire Hathaway stock is certainly flashing warning signs for investors. It failed to stabilize after a drastic decline that started in early November. The RS line is now at its worst level since late 2007.

The RS line, the blue line in the charts, reflects Berkshire's underperformance vs. the S&P 500 index. The fact that any attempts to rally have quickly failed should offer pause for thought.

More broadly, Berkshire stock has lagged the S&P 500 index since the end of 2018. Before that, BRKB stock at best moved with the market for a decade. An investor could have bought an index fund or ETF, like the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY), and generated similar returns with less stock-specific risk.

Berkshire Hathaway Earnings Light
Berkshire Hathaway earnings missed analyst estimates again in Q1. Operating EPS rose 7% to $2.41, while Wall Street had expected Berkshire earnings of $2.51. Nevertheless revenue inched up 1% to $651.3 billion. The value of its stock portfolio plunged from near the $230 billion mark, and now sits at just under $193 billion.

The miss was mainly caused by the firm seeing lower pretax income in nearly every segment. There were two bright spots however. Results for both Geico and Berkshire Hathaway Primary Group, a business unit composed of independent primary insurers, were better than expected. But even then, its operating earnings exclude around $56 billion in after-tax mark-to-market investment and derivative losses.

Berkshire Cash Pile Grows, No Big Bargain Buys
Meanwhile, the firm's cash pile has continued to grow. By the end of Q1, Berkshire's cash pile had swelled to a fresh record high of $137 billion from $128 billion at the end of Q4. Buffett previously complained that "sky high" prices hamstrung his hopes for an "elephant size" acquisition. But low prices now still aren't enough to get him off the sidelines.

Buffett's sidekick Charlie Munger said he and Buffett "just want to get through the typhoon," though he said the firm could still "do something pretty aggressive or seize some opportunity."

The poor results have weighed on the Warren Buffett stock, causing its IBD Composite Rating to fall to just 35. Its score in this key metric has also been trending downward. This means its performance puts it among the bottom 35% of stocks tracked. The Stock Checkup Tool shows a good but not stellar Berkshire earnings-per-share growth rate of 21% over the past three years.

Earnings also can be lumpy. In the last three quarters, Berkshire Hathaway earnings have actually been flat on average. This is not a good sign.

Wall Street is not overly optimistic for Berkshire Hathaway earnings growth, projecting it will fall 4% overall in fiscal 2020, before rebounding with a 13% rise in 2021.

With the coronavirus crisis and severe recession, it's unclear how meaningful Berkshire earnings estimates are.

Earnings ultimately drive stock performance. The CAN SLIM system recommends investors look for companies with earnings and revenue growth of at least 25%.

Difference Between BRKA Stock And BRKB Stock
The most obvious difference between Berkshire Hathaway's A class and B class shares is the price. While — at over 200 a share — BRKB stock may be considered relatively expensive, BRKA stock is the most expensive on the market at more than 300,000 a share.

Warren Buffett decided to introduce the BRKB shares to allow investors to purchase stock directly. Big demand for Berkshire Hathaway stock forced less-moneyed players to plow cash into unit trusts or mutual funds that mirrored his company's holdings.

"As I have told you before, we made this sale (of BRKB shares) in response to the threatened creation of unit trusts that would have marketed themselves as Berkshire look-alikes. In the process, they would have used our past, and definitely non-repeatable, record to entice naive small investors and would have charged these innocents high fees and commissions."

BRKB stock was split 50-for-1 in 2010. It coincided with the firm using stock to help pay for the $27 billion acquisition of railroad Burlington Northern. BRKB shares are now worth 1/1,500th of BRKA stock. However the voting rights were unchanged.

Berkshire Hathaway Today
The modern Berkshire Hathaway operates in four main sectors.

Its insurance group is one of its biggest cash cows. One of the most famous jewels in the crown is Geico, which offers private auto and property insurance. Other parts of this business include multinational property/casualty and life/health reinsurance company General Re and Berkshire Hathaway Reinsurance Group, which underwrites excess-of-loss reinsurance and quota-share coverage globally.

Insurance operations are a big reason why Berkshire Hathaway earnings can be lumpy.

Its Regulated Utility Business group includes Berkshire Hathaway Energy, formerly known as MidAmerican Energy. It also includes railway services arm BNSF, North America's largest freight railroad network.

Meanwhile, the Manufacturing, Service & Retailing group includes Acme Building Brands, Fruit of the Loom and Justin Brands. The likes of Buffalo News, Business Wire, International Dairy Queen and NetJets fall under the service subsector. Retailers include See's Candies, Ben Bridge Jeweler, Helzberg Diamond Shops and Star Furniture.

Finally, the Finance & Financial Products segment includes: Hathaway Credit Corporation, transportation equipment and furniture leasing specialists XTRA and CORT, and BH Finance whose main interest is in proprietary investing strategies.

Berkshire Hathaway Stock Is Not A Buy
Berkshire Hathaway stock has been lagging the S&P 500 index since late 2018 and especially during the coronavirus market rally. Prior to the past 18 months, BRKB stock largely moved with the market. With its broad exposure to firms that have been hit by the coronavirus recession, Berkshire Hathaway's woes may continue.

After a late-2018 burst, Berkshire Hathaway earnings growth has been modest and uneven. Berkshire earnings declined in Q4 last year. In addition, Wall Street sees lukewarm Berkshire earnings in 2020 and 2021.

While it may be presumptuous to bet against Warren Buffett, a canny investor looking for stocks to buy should focus on faster-growing companies, or even a broad-market ETF. The latter is an option espoused by Buffett himself, who says owning an asset such as the SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) is an ideal investment vehicle.

"In my view, for most people, the best thing to do is owning the S&P 500 index fund. If you bet on America and sustain that position for decades, you'd do far better than buying Treasury securities, or far better than following people," he said at Berkshire's annual meeting. "Perhaps with a bias, I don't believe anyone knows what the market is going to do tomorrow, next week, next month, next year."

Bottom line: Berkshire Hathaway stock is not a buy.

fields.title: McDonald's Gets Faster, Leaner Amid Covid-19; Is MCD Stock A Buy?
fields.text:
McDonald's (MCD), the oldest of fast-food names and a Dow Jones stock, just delivered both good news and bad news to Wall Street. U.S. sales have recovered better than expected from the Covid-19 lockdown. But international restaurants, 10% of which remain closed, are still deep in the hole. Yet the Golden Arches looks well-positioned for the post-Covid world, when it may be leaner, faster and ready to pounce with ad dollars and innovative products at the right time. So is now a good time to add McDonald's stock to your buy list?

McDonald's Covid-19 Business Update
In a June 16 update, McDonald's said that global same-store sales fell 20.9% in May vs. a year earlier, after plunging 39% in April. The U.S. was a bright spot, with comparable-store sales down just 5.1% in May vs. a 19.2% fall in April.

International sales have been slower to recover. Company-operated international restaurants saw May same-store sales fall 40.5%, with one-fourth of restaurants still closed. Among restaurants licensed by international operators, sales fell 20%, with about 15% of restaurants still closed at the end of May.

June should see international sales improve, since reopenings happened throughout May in Italy, France and Spain. In June, all U.K. restaurants are set to reopen.

In the U.S., 99% of restaurants remained open for delivery and drive-thru orders. Now more than 1,000 of about 14,000 U.S. restaurants have reopened limited seating.

McDonald's said it would boost ad spending by $200 million to revive sales, recognizing the cost in the second quarter. Early in the Covid-19 crisis, McDonald's suspended stock buybacks and raised $6.5 billion in debt markets to provide a financial cushion and support for franchisees.

Management also said it would cut capital spending by $1 billion this year, amid fewer Experience of the Future remodels and fewer new restaurants. But in the business update, McDonald's said that some franchisees want to go ahead with remodels. While a positive sign, capex won't fall as much as expected.

U.S. fast-food industry restaurant traffic in May fell by roughly 15%, McDonald's said. But the average check size spiked, likely because customers brought home or ordered in meals for the whole family. Actually, lunch and dinner comparable-store sales have fully recovered. Breakfast remains weak, which management attributes to the disruption of regular commutes.

McDonald's Post-Covid
Before Covid-19 hit, it looked like McDonald's might be getting on a roll. The first two months of 2020 saw same-store sales grow a strong 8.1% from a year ago in the U.S. and 7.2% globally, with some help from an extra Leap Day.

The best news: The sales gains "reflected balanced growth in average check and guest counts." After struggling to grow traffic, it looked like McDonald's was beginning to turn the corner.

But as the Covid threat recedes, McDonald's expects some changes to endure. The company slimmed down its menu options to maximize productivity as it closed restaurants in mid-March. CEO Chris Kempczinski said on a June 16 Evercore ISI investor call that such efforts paid off with a 25-second reduction in average drive-thru times. That followed a 20-second reduction in drive-thru times last year, which reversed part of the increase since 2016.

"We're learning what's possible and maybe conventional wisdom of how much you could really do from a capacity standpoint," Kempczinski said. "I think we've learned some things about that through this crisis." McDonald's will eventually expand its menu from the current limited selection. But he called it "probably unlikely" that the menu returns to its pre-Covid size.

When Will McDonald's Enter The Chicken Wars?
On Dec. 2, McDonald's said it was testing a crispy chicken sandwich through Jan. 26 in Knoxville, Tenn., and Houston. McDonald's franchisees have been asking for a chicken sandwich to help traffic trends, with Chick-fil-A gaining in popularity.

During the Q4 earnings call on Jan. 29, Kempczinski told analysts to expect chicken segment news in 2020. "I think we're getting close to having something that we're excited to bring to customers," he said.

Yet Kempczinski said this week, "We've put those plans on the shelf until we had more visibility." Covid also sidetracked a plan for baked goods at breakfast, he said.

Now, having set aside $200 million for advertising, McDonald's is considering when to jump in with chicken and ad dollars.

"The conversations are going on right now."

McDonald's Earnings
First-quarter earnings fell 17% from a year ago amid the Covid hit in March. Even before that, McDonald's earnings saw a lull. Fourth-quarter earnings of $1.97 a share were flat from a year ago, as revenue rose 4% to $5.35 billion.

"What we're focused on is driving growth in operating margin. And our belief is that we're going to have to spend some money in order to be able to drive operating margin," CFO Kevin Ozan said on the Oct. 22 earnings call.

McDonald's has been investing in Experience of the Future remodels, ordering technology including kiosks, and delivery.

In March 2019, McDonald's announced the $300 million acquisition of artificial-intelligence tech company Dynamic Yield. The goal: using AI technology to optimize drive-thru menus to increase purchases, while boosting efficiency and satisfaction. Options could change based on weather, time of day and customers' prior orders. McDonald's said it has rolled out the technology to 11,000 drive-thrus in the U.S.

On Sept. 10, the Golden Arches said it was buying Apprente, a voice-recognition technology company.

BTIG analyst Peter Saleh has written that the eventual deployment of Apprente's voice ordering technology could "largely automate the ordering process, reducing labor hours and more importantly increasing throughput by speeding up the ordering process."

The Bull Case For MCD Stock
"Restaurant upgrades and technology efforts increasingly place McDonald's ahead of major competitors," Saleh wrote in a June 16 note, affirming a buy rating and 220 price target for MCD stock.

With much of its planned investment completed, the combination of a Covid recovery and new product launches could see a return to earnings growth.

Saleh sees EPS falling 24% to $5.95 in 2020, then surging 40% to $8.35 in 2021.

MCD Stock Analysis
MCD stock went on a nice run from August 2018 to August 2019, with the stock rising about 40%. Over the same period, the S&P 500 saw single-digit gains. Fed tightening tripped up the broad stock market, then the China trade war kept investors on edge. McDonald's stock often thrives in difficult economic conditions. Investors also took a shine to the Golden Arches as it embraced fresh beef and artificial intelligence.

That run came to an end as McDonald's missed Q3 2019 earnings and same-store sales estimates and guided toward higher spending. MCD stock tumbled 5% to 199.27 on Oct. 22.

With the stock market in rally mode at the start of 2020, MCD stock made a run back toward its August 2019 high of 221.93. But it came up a bit short, cresting at 218.38 on Feb. 12. Barely a week later, the coronavirus stock market crash arrived, ushering in an unprecedented slump in economic activity.

After falling to a three-year low on March 18, down 43% from its February peak, MCD stock has rebounded with the broad stock market, cutting its losses by nearly three-fourths.

Now the Dow Jones component stands about 6% below a 202.83 buy point in a cup-with-handle base, 10 cents above its Covid-19 rally high on June 8. Since then has pulled back, though mostly on below-average volume, and sits below its 200-day moving average, evidence of lingering technical weakness.

Next, look at the Golden Arches' relative strength line, which shows how MCD stock performs vs. the S&P 500 index. Despite the big rebound for McDonald's stock, its RS line, the blue line in IBD's charts, has been trending lower since March 24, the day after the Dow and S&P 500 hit bottom.

The RS line for McDonald's stock was especially strong during the severe stock market correction in late 2018. Subsequently, the RS line for MCD stock went on to hit an 8-year high in August, before losing steam. On a relative basis, MCD typically outperforms when investors get defensive, and it struggles to keep up when risk is on.

How Does McDonald's Stock Stack Up Vs. Competition?
The Retail-Restaurants industry group has had a pretty strong run and is now ranked No. 36 out of 197 industry groups based on price performance and momentum.

IBD Stock Checkup shows that McDonald's stock isn't among the leaders in the Retail-Restaurants group. McDonald's stock has a mediocre 64 IBD Composite Rating with 99 the top rating. The Composite Rating combines several key fundamental and technical factors into a single score. IBD research shows all-time stock winners often have a Composite Rating of at least 95 near the start of big runs.

McDonald's 59 Relative Strength Rating, better than 59% of all stocks, ranks No. 26 in its industry group. By comparison, burger rival Wendy's (WEN) has a 94 RS rating, Shake Shack (SHAK) 55 and Burger King parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) 78.

Among leading restaurant stocks, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has a 92 RS rating, Domino's Pizza (DPZ) stock has an 84 RS rating, while Wingstop (WING) stock has a 95 rating.

Is McDonald's Stock A Buy?
McDonald's sales will likely continue to rebound, but longer-term revenue growth has been anemic in recent years.

McDonald's stock is about 6% below a proper buy point in a cup-with-handle base. In fast-food terms, it's a bit undercooked. While MCD stock could be putting together the ingredients for a run, new investors should wait for a good entry point once McDonald's exhibits strength relative to the broad stock market.

Bottom line: McDonald's stock is not a buy. 

As long as the stock market uptrend remains intact per IBD's daily The Big Picture column, investors may find better buying opportunities in younger, faster-growing companies. To find the best stocks to buy or watch, check out IBD Stock Lists and other IBD content.
